discussion.content:
You can pause definition as well. A lot of resources is confirming that.

Some cumulative updates are designed to fix problems within Windows 10 & if you use Windows Defender then the definition files are updated via Windows update so pausing updates would also pause these.
source: https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/can-i-pause-windows-10-updates-for-35-days/827d2c79-df9b-4e47-ab76-5e3b770a5d2b

Pause Updates. This option allows the user to defer updates for up to 35 days, including security updates.
source: MD-100T00-A - Windows Client official book

I also tried my self, I even recorded it. Later I will come back and share a youtube video link.

When you check for updates there it is security definitions from Microsoft Defender and when you hit the pause for 7 days (assuming you can reach 35), everything stops.
Answers are correct

comments.content: I'm not sure as this thread says the definition updates are paused too. Feel free to link anything that says otherwise https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/does-pausing-windows-update-cause-windows-defender/7a074ad4-c699-4e7b-8817-3a6a12c51fc3
Scroll down to the last comment

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You manage Windows updates for a computer that runs Windows 10.
You need to identify the following:
✑ Which update types can be paused
✑ The maximum number of days that the updates can be paused
What should you identify? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Feature updates and quality updates only
Quality updates can be paused.
Feature updates can be deferred.

Box 2: 35 -
Quality updates can be paused for up to 35 days.
Note: To help ensure device compliance and user productivity, Microsoft sends different types of updates including:
Quality updates. These monthly updates include bug fixes and security enhancements. Because quality updates are cumulative and don't require a complete reinstallation, the packages are smaller, and they download and install quickly.
Feature updates. These twice-yearly updates include new features and significant enhancements to the Windows operating system.
Device driver updates. These small pieces of software are the updates made to the device drivers by original equipment manufacturer (OEM) vendors. Microsoft
Update is used as a channel for distributing these updates.
Microsoft Defender definition updates. These updates include current threat information for Microsoft Defender.
Reference:
https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/hybrid-work/managing-windows-10-updates-for-a-remote-work-world/m-p/1510387

discussion.content:
N,N,N

A mandatory user profile is a roaming user profile that has been pre-configured by an administrator to specify settings for users. Settings commonly defined in a mandatory profile include (but are not limited to): icons that appear on the desktop, desktop backgrounds, user preferences in Control Panel, printer selections, and more. Configuration changes made during a user's session that are normally saved to a roaming user profile are not saved when a mandatory user profile is assigned.
The .man extension causes the user profile to be a read-only profile.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/mandatory-user-profile
The local profile will not be used when configured with a mandatory network profile. So all changes after the mandatory profile is in place will not be saved. It doesn't matter which computer.

I would say : N,N,N
Explanation :
A mandatory user profile is a special type of pre-configured roaming user profile that administrators can use to specify settings for users. With mandatory user profiles, a user can modify his or her desktop, but the changes are not saved when the user logs off. The next time the user logs on, the mandatory user profile created by the administrator is downloaded.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/desktop/legacy/bb776895(v=vs.85)

Os perfis de usuário contêm um arquivo chamado NTuser.dat.

A parte do usuário do registro. Os perfis do usuário contêm um arquivo chamado NTuser.dat

https://docs.microsoft.com/pt-br/training/modules/explore-authentication/9-explore-user-profiles-contents?pivots=bash

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: No -
User profiles become mandatory profiles when the administrator renames the NTuser.dat file (the registry hive) of each user's profile in the file system of the profile server from NTuser.dat to NTuser.man. The .man extension causes the user profile to be a read-only profile.
A mandatory user profile is a roaming user profile that has been pre-configured by an administrator to specify settings for users. Settings commonly defined in a mandatory profile include (but are not limited to): icons that appear on the desktop, desktop backgrounds, user preferences in Control Panel, printer selections, and more. Configuration changes made during a user's session that are normally saved to a roaming user profile are not saved when a mandatory user profile is assigned.

Box 2: Yes -
The local profile will still be updated and saved.
In a local user profile, the setting changes made to a computer are saved locally on that computer.

Box 3: No -
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/mandatory-user-profile
questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your network contains an on-premises Active Directory forest named contoso.com. The forest contains a user named User1 and two computers named
Computer1 and Computer2 that run Windows 10.
User1 is configured as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

You rename file \\Server1\Profiles\User1.V6\NTUSER.DAT as NTUSER.MAN.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

Your network contains an on-premises Active Directory domain. The domain contains two computers named Computer1 and Computer2 that run Windows 10.
You install Windows Admin Center on Computer1.
You need to manage Computer2 from Computer1 by using Windows Admin Center.
What should you do on Computer2?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct

When you access the Windows Admin Center platform and add a new computer (Windows PC) without any configuration yet, you will get the message as shown below. This confirms definitively that it is necessary to perform the configuration of the response in question.

“Connecting to remote server (COMPUTER NAME) failed with the following error message: WinRM cannot complete the operation. Verify that the specified computer name is valid, that the computer is accessible over the network, and that a firewall exception for the WinRM service is enabled and allows access from this computer. By default, the WinRM firewall exception for public profiles limits access to remote computers within the same local subnet.”

Selected Answer: B
Correct

choices.B: Allow Windows Remote Management (WinRM) through the Microsoft Defender firewall.
choices.A: Add an inbound Microsoft Defender Firewall rule.

comments.content:
It seems that since Windows 7 the guest profile is allowed to save files to desktop and user folders. So that brings me back to 2-2-2 for this example.
https://www.digitalcitizen.life/simple-questions-what-guest-account-how-turn-it/
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/guest-account-saves-data/8aa2f013-c7aa-4f48-ac81-a0f3cd0f88dc

discussion.content:
2 - 2 - 3
My lab experiment:
u1 will see its own file (f1) and the public file (f2)
u2 will see the public file (f2) and the default file (f3) because of the first time sign-on
u3 will see its own file (f4), the public file (f2) and the default file (f3) because Windows wipes off guest profiles every time

comments.content: don't forget the question is : How many DOCX files will appear on the desktop of each user the NEXT TIME each user signs in

discussion.content:
I've also tested in my lab and have concluded :
-user1 File1 and File2 (file3 will not be visible because the user was already connected on the pc with his account) 
-user2 File2 and File3
-user3 File2 and File3 (File4 is deleted after signing out because it's a Guest account)
so 2-2-2

comments.content: Dont forget its for next login ... so user 2 see file 2 and 3

discussion.content:
CHatGPT
User1:
File1.docx (C:\Users\User1\Desktop\File1.docx)
File2.docx (C:\Users\Public\Public Desktop\File2.docx)
File3.docx (C:\Users\Default\Desktop\File3.docx)
Total: 3
User2:
Since user2 has never signed in, there won't be any files on their desktop.

User3:

File4.docx (C:\Users\User3\Desktop\File4.docx)
Total: 1
Therefore, the number of DOCX files that will appear on the desktop of each user the next time they sign in will be:

User1: 3
User2: 0
User3: 1
What a worthless site... seems every answer they pose is wrong. Time to find a new site I guess. Simple one like this and they get that wrong, wow !!!

User1 - 2 (File1 and File2)
User2 - 2 (File2 and File3)
User3 - 2 (File2 and File3)

easily tested in a laboratory environment.

- Default only adds File3 to new users who have never logged into the system.
- The File4 file will be created by User3 himself, but User3 is a guest user and his data will be deleted after the first sign out. So every time User3 logs back in, File2 and File3 are recreated.

The next time User1 signs in to Computer1, they will see two DOCX files on their desktop: File1.docx and File3.docx.
The next time User2 signs in to Computer1, they will see one DOCX file on their desktop: File3.docx.
The next time User3 signs in to Computer1, they will see one DOCX file on their desktop: File4.docx.
Note that File2.docx in the Public Desktop folder will be accessible to all users of Computer1, but it will not appear on the desktop of any individual user.

Guys, please test before writing. Correct answers should be:

user1 - File1 and FIle2
user2 - File2 and File3
user3 - File2 and File4

So the answer:
2-2-2

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10.
Computer has the users shown in the following table.
//IMG//

User1 signs in to Computer1, creates the following files, and then signs out:
✑ File1.docx in C\Users\User1\Desktop
✑ File2.docx in C:\Users\Public\Public Desktop
✑ File3.docx in C:\Users\Default\Desktop
User3 then signs in to Computer1 and creates a file named File4.docx in C:\Users\User3\Desktop.
User2 has never signed in to Computer1.
How many DOCX files will appear on the desktop of each user the next time each user signs in? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: 3 -
File1, File2 and File3.
C:\Users\Public\Desktop is the CommonDesktopDirectory special folder.
The "public desktop" folder is normally a hidden folder.

Box 2: 1 -
Only File3.

Box 3: 1 -
User3 is a guest so only the public desktop folder and File3 in that folder is displayed.
Reference:
https://superuser.com/questions/984866/how-to-make-a-desktop-shortcut-available-for-all-users-in-windows-10

Box 1: Cleanup recommendations -
Cleanup recommendations, Click on Unused apps, select the apps and click the Clean up button.


Box 2: Storage Sense -
Windows Storage Sense is a silent assistant that works with OneDrive to automatically free up space by making locally available files that you aren't using anymore online-only again. Online-only files stay safe in OneDrive and are visible on your device.
Cleanup Recommendations on Windows 11 is a feature to automate the process of identifying the contents you can delete to help free up hard drive space on the computer.
The feature is part of the Storage settings, and it automatically detects and displays the amount of space that Windows 11 can be reclaimed by deleting certain large or unused files, uninstalling apps that you do not use, and clearing copies of files already uploaded to OneDrive.

Box 3: Disk Cleanup -
Run Disk Cleanup to clean Windows Defender folder safely. It will delete non critical files used by Windows Defender.
Reference:
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/use-onedrive-and-storage-sense-in-windows-10-to-manage-disk-space-de5faa9a-6108-4be1-87a6- d90688d08a48 https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/5798a3fc-4032-4d1a-976a-ac566fe502cd/is-it-safe-to-clean-windows-defender-folder? forum=win10itprogeneral

discussion.content:
Unused Apps: Cleanup recommendations
Unused OneDrive content: Storage Sense

Storage Sense is a built-in feature in Windows 10 and can be used to manage storage on your local device as well as cloud storage services like OneDrive.
Non-critical files for Microsoft Defender Antivirus: Disk Cleanup
Answers are correct

Unused Apps: Cleanup recommendations
Unused OneDrive content: Cleanup recommendations
Non-critical files for Microsoft Defender Antivirus: Disk Cleanup
Note: Storage Sense in Windows 10 cannot clean up unused OneDrive content. Storage Sense is designed to free up disk space by removing temporary files, system files, and other unneeded files that are stored locally on your computer. It does not have the ability to clean up files that are stored in the cloud.

comments.content:
This is correct. Stora Sense can make OneDrive files online only and delete them locally.
Unused files, on the other hand, are in the Cleanup Recommendations.

You can check for yourself on your device.

I misinterpreted a sentence on the description of the operating system.
I changed my opinion. The answers given are correct to the current date.

discussion.content: Answers look correct
